title: Will Boom Technology's XB-1 supersonic aircraft complete a successful test flight before 2022?
preds:
From a recent (Dec 20) piece in Wired (https://www.wired.com/story/boom-supersonic-planes/ ):
----------------
Blake Scholl, Boom’s cofounder and CEO [...] tells me I’ve come at a propitious moment. “This is actually a really big week,” he says as we don safety hats and glasses, “because we powered up the airplane for the first time this week. And then fuel goes onboard the airplane for the first time on Sunday. And then we’re just a few weeks away from running the engines.” At some point down the road, on a test strip in the Mojave Desert, the XB-1 will have a taxi test, and, at some point after that, a flight test. 
----------------- cf my comment and forecast (18%) of May 10 (when the crowd estimation was at 73%): https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1274832 cc @probahilliby (we had some exchange about engine and other tests in the past) My guess, today? We are talking at *best* for April 2022 (emphasis at "best").
They have announced they will not.
"we’re not flying yet (lots of ground testing left). But XB-1 did hit a major pre-flight test milestone today [Nov 21]" https://twitter.com/bscholl/status/1462206001386377224
Its virgin they aint tge fastest horse in the corral but they will get there. not to mention economic conditions are holding back everything
Nothing has been announced by now, which makes the probability of it happening by the end of the year zero. They would want a lot of publicity long before the flight.
I could be surprised, but that would surprise me.
Passage of time, no changes. I guess new developments could surprise me, but I'd be surprised.

Next week on 60 Minutes: Supersonic passenger planes, shows the actual test plain in the hanger, not eve close
https://www.cbsnews.com/video/next-week-on-60-minutes-supersonic-passenger-planes/

They've just been named on Time's best inventions of 2021 (1), which is a nice touch and bodes well for the company's future, but given the time to the end of the year, I don't think it's likely they will launch a test flight in 2021 (can you imagine asking test pilots to take the risk just before Christmas?) 1. https://time.com/collection/best-inventions-2021/6112684/xb-1-boom-supersonic/

Short (5 mins) video by CBS: "successful test flights, next year [...]" (~ 0:49)
https://twitter.com/cbsmornings/status/1451899857069817859
Less confident. Cannot find anything recent to suggest this is on course. Maybe early 2022 is the plan now.

Must be really tiring for the CEO to go out there and bullshit every day. Its twitter is also filled with fairly inane content. I also think that they wouldn't be talking all that much about carbon neutral flight if they had more exciting things to talk about, such as a working prototype. Going down.
https://www.voanews.com/a/supersonic-commercial-air-travel-to-return-by-end-of-decade/6257871.html
https://boomsupersonic.com/flyby/
https://twitter.com/boomaero
I believe that the test will need into ‘22 to complete arrangements
3 months left and it seems like there's nothing planned. No news on this and I would think an upcoming test would be of media interest.

According to a Sep 18 report by Fortune, "The prototype [...] should take its first test-flight early next year": https://archive.is/4NlCX#selection-599.221-599.328 This is consistent with the most recent news report before that, on Aug 18: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1323074

These things seem to get held up. Base rate for experimental planes seems to be a slow release. 
Other hand: Scaled Composites do prototype planes,, they seems to have a rate of 1 new plane every 2 years or so. So this makes me a little more bullish.(having said that making prototype planes is their bread and butter).
Seems a lot of new tech in this plane, different from normal planes. On other hand, this is a scaled down prototype.
I am unaware of any engine testing. - assume there is some stress testing required.
Planes are complex, everything has to be right, all they need is one hard issue to hold them up. It's easy to underestimate complexity.

I have read aviation trades that mention sightings of various but concerning ufo's that travel in a straight steak with no UFO hijinx. I wonder if it will be reveled in time for this questions time frame.

Esta pregunta resulta interesante ya que boom, una empresa privada que se encuentra desarrollando un avión comercial supersónico de tamaño intermedio (65 -68) pasajeros, planea testear su primer prototipo de menor escala a fines de 2021 y principios de 2022. en este prototípo solo cabe el piloto. Boom liberó mostró el diseño por primera vez en 2016 y tenía planeado el primer vuelo en 2017, pero todavía no haourrido. Considerando que el concorde se demoró 15 años desde la etapa de diseño inicial hasta su primer vuelo, boom va por buen camino. Concorde tenía varios desafíos técnicos por superar para poder transportar pasajeros, por lo que su desarrollo no fue fácil. Puede parecer que gracias a este avión boom ya tiene la investigación lista, pero se está dedicando a resolver un problema que concorde nunca solucionó, disminuir los decibeles del boom sónico para poder volar sobre tierra (donde vive gente) y agregar una gama de destinos a los cuales concorde nunca pudo llegar.  Por lo que boom tiene diseños y ideas nuevas que hay que testear y asegurar su seguridad para volar pasajeros. Yo preveo con relativa confianza que el vuelo si ocurrirá antes del 2022 ya que Boom es una empresa privada ,el desarrollo de concorde fue liderado por el estado francés e inglés, y los privados suelen ser más agiles que los estados. Además hoy en día con nuevas técnicas de manufacturación, de diseño y nuevos materiales que antes no existían es más facil diseñar y prototipar que hace 52 años.

I'm moving towards anything between 15% and 35%. On the 15% side, the CEO has started talking about 2022, and delays have been abundant in the past. On the 35% side, they have begun testing the flight vision system, which seems like maybe one of the last steps (?). Also, Laplace doesn't quite feel right for bus-waiting problems (where the longer you wait, the closer the bus is to arriving, even if you don't know when it will arrive.)

Norris. G. (2021, July 26). Boom Tests Vision System For XB-1 Supersonic Demonstrator. Aviation Week. Retrieved from
https://aviationweek.com/air-transport/aircraft-propulsion/boom-tests-vision-system-xb-1-supersonic-demonstrator Supersonic airliner developer Boom is evaluating a forward-looking vision system (FLVS) as part of preparations for flight tests of the XB-1 high-speed demonstrator as well as design planning for the follow-on full-scale Overture passenger aircraft. Similar to the External Vision System (XVS) developed for NASA’s X-59 Quiet Supersonic Technology low-boom demonstrator, the FLVS will provide a virtual view of the runway to aid pilots in approach and landing. Both the X-59 and XB-1 have long noses which, unlike the drooping nose section of the long-retired supersonic Concorde airliner, are fixed—and present visibility challenges at the high angles of attack required for landing highly swept wing designs. The system has been flight tested at Mojave Air & Space Port, California, using a specially modified Velocity—a kit-built canard pusher design. The aircraft was selected because it “was able to achieve speeds on approach similar to that of XB-1,” says Boom. “Another benefit of using this aircraft was the pusher prop, which allows the camera system to be easily mounted where it was unobstructed,” adds the developer. The FLVS incorporates two cameras, a multifunctional display, a data acquisition system, an inertial navigation system and, after a series of flights, was deemed acceptable for use in the XB-1 by Boom test pilots. Testing included more than 50 approaches under a variety of conditions including crosswinds, haze and into the glare of the rising sun.  The FLVS will be installed by the nose leg of the one-third scale XB-1 demonstrator which is expected to begin flights later in 2021 or early 2022. The 71-ft.-long trijet design is undergoing final ground tests at Boom’s Centennial, Colorado headquarters.
Going down 3% after no new comments appeared since the points made last week.
The annoying thing about research is it often yields new information, or new ways to think about existing information.  It never yields bourbon.  Coming down some more.
I said I'd drop down to 5%, but I'll go to just 10% because of @cdob63's bias toward yes.
I'll go downwards more in the upcoming weeks, but comments below check out.

Possibility of early completion but indicators tell me it's too soon. I see that maiden test flights for major planes don't usually occur in the last couple months of the year, which is when the plane could be ready for testing. However, if it is completed, typically they would conduct an array of ground tests first. This may take some time. THEN, they typically proceed into flight tests. I was thrown off that they are still building it when I had thought they already built it. Perhaps it was all for show and they are now fitting it with all the technology and sensors needed for a test flight. From video footage in the hangar, it seems they already have the plane put together as a whole. This may mean they are soon to begin ground testing and soon flight testing. ntscc

The official line appears to now be a 2022 test flight. I'd be pretty surprised if, given the pandemic and so on, the timescale moved forwards rather at this stage. https://www.travelpulse.com/news/airlines/is-the-future-of-air-travel-supersonic.html
A first flight is typically just a takeoff and landing. The real tests always come much later. All in.
Maybe they'll finish the project early.
Updating in light of convincing news, consistent with lots of the signs that they are not on schedule. Perhaps most telling is the miss on test flights this summer. @jleibowich - Safe to land at 0%?

Reuters:
"Boom is building a 1/3 scale prototype of the aircraft and hopes to begin test flights in 2022". Their chief test pilot explains the rationale:
"From the airplane standpoint, in the lead into first flight, we're going to try and put the airplane through its paces as much as we can on the ground. We want to put the airplane through a set of conditions that are as representative of a flight as we possibly can. So by doing that, we're left with as few surprises as we can possibly have in flight.” Works on the XB-1 can be seen in the background of the video. https://www.reuters.com/video/watch/startup-aims-to-revive-supersonic-flight-idOVEQOBROF
https://uk.news.yahoo.com/startup-aims-revive-supersonic-flights-213345671.html (with transcript)
-15, decided to lean against as there hasn't been any recent news I've seen and only 4 months left.

Cision PR Newswire, Website,  (2021, July 30). Boom Supersonic and Rolls-Royce Agree on New Collaboration for Supersonic Overture Engine Program Design. Retrieved from
https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/boom-supersonic-and-rolls-royce-agree-on-new-collaboration-for-supersonic-overture-engine-program-design-301103138.html DENVER, July 30, 2020 /PRNewswire/ -- Boom Supersonic, an aerospace company building the world's fastest civil aircraft, and leading industrial technology company, Rolls-Royce, today announced an engagement agreement to explore the pairing of a Rolls-Royce propulsion system with Boom's flagship supersonic passenger aircraft, Overture.

Gonna put some doubt based on the fact that they're still hiring a lot of positions and posting much about the development side of the aircraft, which gives me the impression that they are still in elementary stages. On the other hand, what they post does not necessarily correlate to where they are in the project and jobs are always being sought, especially since the Overture phase of the project is still far out, etc., etc.

Shapiro, A. (2021, June 8). Test flights for superfast jets will 'be in the air in just a matter of months': Boom Supersonic CEO. Yahoo News. Retrieved from
https://finance.yahoo.com/news/test-flights-for-superfast-jets-will-be-in-the-air-in-just-a-matter-of-months-boom-supersonic-ceo-110933170.html

If Virgin Galactic can do it, why would Boom fail?
If the US authorities are willing to promote and make Space Travel happen, why would they not engage in a new supersonic industry?

+10%. I looked at the Mojave desert's climate, and its very hot in summer, while being very tolerable in winter. This suggests that September-December would be a nice time to carry out the tests, as opposed to right now. This undoes some of my passage of time updating.

Supersonic flight has already been established as workable in both commercial and military flights. However the track record of new companies in space and supersonic flight is marred by over promising and under delivering so it is possible there is a delay till 2022.
Takes into account time passed, the current goal, and my range of possibilities I think are reasonable.

First flight of Boom’s XB-1 demonstrator could happen next year: CEO
-
Hemmerdinger, (2021) April, 27, Stated That:
-
The chief executive of Boom Supersonic has left open the possibility that the company’s supersonic demonstrator may not get airborne until next year.
-
CEO Blake Scholl says Boom expects the jet’s first flight will occur “around the end of this year, early next year”.
\
Reference
\
Hemmerdinger, J.   (2021, April, 27). First flight of Boom’s XB-1 demonstrator could happen next year: CEO. Flight Global. Retrieved from
https://www.flightglobal.com/airframers/first-flight-of-booms-xb-1-demonstrator-could-happen-next-year-ceo/143485.article \
\
United Adding Supersonic Speeds with New Agreement to Buy Aircraft from Boom Supersonic -
CHICAGO and DENVER, June 3, 2021 /PRNewswire/ -- United Airlines today announced a commercial agreement with Denver-based aerospace company Boom Supersonic to add aircraft to its global fleet as well as a cooperative sustainability initiative – a move that facilitates a leap forward in returning supersonic speeds to aviation.
-
Under the terms of the agreement, United will purchase 15 of Boom's 'Overture' airliners, once Overture meets United's demanding safety, operating and sustainability requirements, with an option for an additional 35 aircraft. The companies will work together on meeting those requirements before delivery. Once operational, Overture is expected to be the first large commercial aircraft to be net-zero carbon from day one, optimized to run on 100% sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). It is slated to roll out in 2025, fly in 2026 and expected to carry passengers by 2029. United and Boom will also work together to accelerate production of greater supplies of SAF. \
References
\
United Airlines, Website. (2021, June 3). United Adding Supersonic Speeds with New Agreement to Buy Aircraft from Boom Supersonic. United. Newsroom Release. Retrieved from
https://hub.united.com/2021-06-03-united-adding-supersonic-speeds-with-new-agreement-to-buy-aircraft-from-boom-supersonic-2653216403.html
Looking at actual pictures of the XB-1, it's difficult to say to what extent it exists: https://www.businessinsider.com/supersonic-startup-boom-unveils-xb-1-prototype-begins-flight-testing-2020-10

In a recent interview, the CEO was asked: "This plane is expected to test flight, the XB-1, at the end of this year, early next year, right?", and he answers "Yeah, that's right". If it was definitely going to happen this year, I imagine that he would have corrected the reporter. In particular, because he bullshits so much in the rest of the video and is otherwise so optimistic, the fact that he doesn't do that here is a signal. Going down ~15% based on that.
https://in.finance.yahoo.com/news/test-flights-for-superfast-jets-will-be-in-the-air-in-just-a-matter-of-months-boom-supersonic-ceo-110933170.html, 2:14
Looking at the contract with the Mojave airport https://boomsupersonic.com/news/post/boom-supersonic-mojave-supersonic-corridor, I also don't see *dates* mentioned.

The CEO just bullshits so much: https://in.finance.yahoo.com/news/test-flights-for-superfast-jets-will-be-in-the-air-in-just-a-matter-of-months-boom-supersonic-ceo-110933170.html
Also, here is the Mojave desert contract: https://boomsupersonic.com/news/post/boom-supersonic-mojave-supersonic-corridor

Raising the chances a little, but I am still not entirely convinced, partly due to thinking "what's the rush?" Given timelines extend to the end of the decade, a couple of months either way at this stage seems less important. Why rush and risk a failure? I am curious if there is an incentive to test a prototype that is not supersonic capable in order to meet the deadline (for financial reasons perhaps). For example, specific components needing further development before the prototype could physically reach supersonic speeds (e.g. an engine not powerful enough as it stands). Somewhat unrelated, the market for this is curious. The statements made related to the United deal suggested (without detail) the aircraft would be carbon neutral. I am slightly sceptical about how this will work or 'fly' politically. Supersonic flight over land is tightly regulated in many places. Perhaps the trans-Atlantic & trans-Pacific routes provide enough of a market. Are the EU and US likely to relax rules to allow Europe-Far East and Europe-West Coast routes, where the supersonic travel is most advantageous? Is there a way to create routes from the Middle East hubs that overfly the Indian ocean, and southern Asia (India, Pakistan, Iran (!), and Chine to access those Far East routes - esp. Japan, eastern China and perhaps Australia.
It feels like such a massive step away from the demand for electric aircraft and the move away from carbon intensive travel.

He seems a bit more confident here
Boom's prototype experimental aircraft called the XB-1 will start test flights later this year. "That's our prototype for the Overture airliner. It rolled out last fall and it's going to be in the air in just a matter of months," Scholl said. The goal is to roll out the first Overture jet in 2025 and begin test flights in 2026.
https://in.finance.yahoo.com/news/test-flights-for-superfast-jets-will-be-in-the-air-in-just-a-matter-of-months-boom-supersonic-ceo-110933170.html
+5% on recent announcements of interest by United; I imagine that it correlates with Boom being on schedule

Many of the interviews from project leaders on XB-1 have very credible resumes... smart individuals probably with great rationality. Not one doubted the timeline and all cited the testing planned for this summer. Makes me question why I should go against them, who know more information than we do. We, the public, can't even predict when they'll be doing cabin and ground tests. Why wouldn't they test it this year? They have to get back to work; this is their job. They can't just wait 7 months and then decide to take off January. Then again, low sample size and huge blindspot on this topic. It does not make sense that they would start training for testing and then start 7 months later, though it is possible that they take 3 months to train, 3 months to test most things prior to flight test, and then get into the sky in early 2022.

Slotnick, D. (2021, June, 3). United Airlines announces deal with Boom Supersonic for faster-than-sound commercial flights. The Points Guy. Retrieved from
https://thepointsguy.com/news/united-airlines-boom-supersonic/ This post contains references to products from one or more of our advertisers. We may receive compensation when you click on links to those products. Terms apply to the offers listed on this page. For an explanation of our Advertising Policy, visit this page. United Airlines said on Thursday that it had signed a deal with Boom Supersonic, a startup working to develop the first supersonic commercial jet since the Concorde, to purchase up to 50 of the company’s planned passenger jet. Under the deal, United would purchase 15 of Boom’s Overture jet, which the startup plans to enter into commercial service in 2029, with the option for up to 35 more.

Given developments and even a failure in 2021, 2022 test would be likely successful and with airlines starting to place orders, this is likely but the 75% is because there may be a delay in development which always happen but delays are less and less with developments in technology.

So apparently, a manufacturing facility is scheduled to break ground in 2022 and be completed for aircraft production around 2023. That gives the company this year and next year to flight test the XB-1 and decide on changes it wants to make before they start building the thing in 2023. They are gearing up as evidenced by recent hires and the recent deal with United Airlines. Given reports of ground testing underway a flight test of the 1/3 scale model doesn't sound so far off. The actual test flights for the full-sized Overture will be around 2026. That means XB-1 flight test can happen in either 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024, or 2025. That's a 20% chance this year. However, you factor in that they want to start building by 2023. That leaves 2021 and 2022, or 50%. I wonder what kind of implications Aerion's shutting down means for Overture. Will that mean more resources and lessons learned are available at Boom Technology's disposable? Or does that mean a more sinister ending is at Overture's fate, too? Side note: I don't think they're at risk as a business, given a recent hire of a financial leader. Now back to the CEO's doubt on project timeline. He said he was doubting the completion of a flight test this year, saying that the end of this year or the start of next year is the main thinking. However, we don't know if he anticipated that COVID would not be as restrictive come this summer onwards. He may have assumed that COVID would still be an obstacle for the progress of Overture. Thoughts? @DNK89 @Quincel1 @Sports_and_Science If anyone has the guts to ask him directly, he was a Twitter.

As per report
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/06/03/united-will-buy-15-ultrafast-airplanes-from-start-up-boom-supersonic.html
United Airlines has ordered 15 Boom "Ouvertures" and has an option for 35 more units.
"Ouverture" is set to go into production between 2023 and 2025 (differing between sources) and will tentatively fly in 2026 for the first time.
Regular service with passengers is envisioned for 2029.
In total, Boom now has orders for 70 units. There is a major issue with carbon/fuel efficiency, since in a "per passenger" analysis, the Ouverture will burn five to seven times as much fuel as conventional planes; however, the company seems certain to be able to adress the issue and make it a "carbon-neutral plane" (how exactly, they do not disclose...). The key takeaways are:
/the option of finally selling the Ouverture becomes more realistic, as Boom now has at least two major carriers as clients
/the pressure on Boom grows to bring XB-1 into the air and demonstrate feasibility of this concept, not least to their clients, in exchange for advance payments. "The company plans to make its first flight later this year with a demonstrator jet called the XB-1. If it goes as planned, Boom will begin production of the Overture in 2023 and conduct its first flight in 2026. The ultimate hurdle will be winning certification by regulators, including the Federal Aviation Administration."
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/06/03/united-will-buy-15-ultrafast-airplanes-from-start-up-boom-supersonic.html "In October, Boom unveiled a smaller demonstration model, the XB-1, which the company expects to use for test flights beginning this year."
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-03/united-bets-on-supersonic-future-with-3-billion-boom-jet-order @cdob63

No variation in my forecast, just to share that supersonic business jet developer Aerion has unexpectedly ceased operations after 18 years and backing by Boeing: https://www.flightglobal.com/business-aviation/supersonic-business-jet-developer-aerion-folds/143867.article

Increasing only very slightly (from 18 to 19%) due to the cabin pressure tests announced by the CEO in Twitter in April (h/t @probahilliby): https://twitter.com/bscholl/status/1387604718264872961 . Still puzzled why such tests do not get more publicity.

Back up because an article I read on one of the forecasters here states that testing is the Mojave Dessert is expected in mid-2021. Although that period of time is monsoon season for that region (assumption), its driest months on average are May and June - which is now. But what about the future? I also see that currently as of this month, the CEO has said that XB-1 has undergone cabin pressurization tests. I also see that this aircraft has new techonology that had been tested. Who knows whether it needs further testing or if other new technology is still being put together. One article says that they are currently in the process of training for testing this year. I assume training entails lots and lots of preparation in itself. I also question the timing because usually when commercial aircraft have their first test flight, it takes a year or more to get introduced into the commercial market. If the current plan is 2023 then sure testing in 2021 sounds consistent. If 2025, then why have a maiden flight so soon? https://blog.boomsupersonic.com/how-technology-is-solving-one-of-the-biggest-supersonic-design-challenges-visibility-e269789f411a https://blog.boomsupersonic.com/tomorrows-air-travel-is-supersonic-and-sustainable-12e39244dbce https://twitter.com/bscholl/status/1387604718264872961
Even the CEO has doubts. CEOs are most likely and should be cheerleaders for their projects. But because the aim is around the end of the year, I cannot be so sure.

Won't increase until I see evidence that they are beginning basic taxiing, systems, engines, tests, etc. I think this is crucial for an aircraft to go through and it is quite odd that it has not been reported or publicized for such a high-profile "revolutionary" aircraft. I expect to go down further if this point goes unchallenged. Engine tests don't necessarily have to be isolated tests from the main fuselage, correct? h/t @ctsats

Boom's CEO leaning into the hype: Boom Supersonic aims to fly 'anywhere in the world in four hours for $100' - CNN 
https://www.cnn.com/travel/article/boom-supersonic-four-hours-100-bucks/index.html
Mon, 17 May 2021 12:04:31 GMT This reduces the amount of good faith I'm willing to predict he is acting with. No change in the forecast

From other links here sounds like they're aiming for the end of the year but they have a history of delays too. I'll give them the slight benefit of the doubt right now. I definitely think I anchored to the crowd forecast and was also too optimistic. Need to be aware of that in the future.

Not quite sure why the crowd is so optimistic here. XB-1 was initially targeted to start flight tests back in 2019, only to be pushed back to 2020 [1]. CEO then said ""This is an ambitious project. In the early days it is easy to underestimate what is required" [1] and I couldn't agree more. Later, the flight tests were postponed to 2021, only to be hinted last April by the CEO that the jet’s first flight will occur “around the end of this year, early next year” [2] (h/t @DNK89, although, curiously enough, I cannot find any corroboration for this statement, other than [2]; it is not included in his congressional hearing [3] - UPDATE see https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oeSeOKFvNgY , 8:50-9:00, h/t @DNK89 below). The FAA rules for supersonic flight [4, 5] is indeed a concern, but truth is that, for the question to be answered positively, the aircraft does not need to actually go supersonic; a simple "dry run" test (take off, fly around for a while, and land without even attempting to go supersonic) will be more than enough for a successful first flight (in fact it is certain that there will be several subsonic test flights before the first supersonic attempt; we call it "envelope expansion"). And it is due to this possibility that I am maintaining a 18% chance - not that I expect any actual supersonic flight before 2022. But even that is far from trivial or certain within the given time context. There are many things to be completed before even a routine first flight, such as engine runs, a whole bunch of static & system tests, and taxiing tests, about which we have yet to hear anything (I doubt that they might have happened and not announced, as they are also good for the PR & marketing).  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
[1]: https://www.flightglobal.com/strategy/paris-boom-xb-1-schedule-slips-while-jal-eyes-overture/133222.article
[2]: https://www.flightglobal.com/airframers/first-flight-of-booms-xb-1-demonstrator-could-happen-next-year-ceo/143485.article
[3]: https://transportation.house.gov/imo/media/doc/Scholl%20Testimony1.pdf
[4]: https://www.aviationtoday.com/2021/01/08/faa-announces-final-rules-supersonic-flight-testing-us/
[5]: https://www.faa.gov/news/media/attachments/SFA_Supersonic_Final_Rule.pdf

Thanks to @Quincel1 and @DNK89 for the reference to the Flight Global link.
The lack of progress and dates going into May suggests this is unlikely. Not out of the question, but less confident than I was.

@DNK89 has found the evidence for the theory I've been suspecting might exist. CEO says the timetable has slipped, now near the end of this year or early 2022. https://www.flightglobal.com/airframers/first-flight-of-booms-xb-1-demonstrator-could-happen-next-year-ceo/143485.article
Listening to @Quincel1 and @DNK89 and decreasing confidence for "Yes".

CEO Blake Scholl says Boom expects the jet’s first flight will occur “around the end of this year, early next year”.
https://www.flightglobal.com/airframers/first-flight-of-booms-xb-1-demonstrator-could-happen-next-year-ceo/143485.article
Maybe this is a good time to reflect and revisit
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planning_fallacy

We are 1/3rd of the way through 2021 and we have no information, set date, visible progress, or other indicator that this is happening. I don't think Boom is going to collapse or something, but the risk of delays seem very real.

XB-1's competition in low boom supersonic flight: "Atlanta-based Hermeus Corporation is working on a hypersonic 20-seater that promises to deliver passengers from New York to London in 90 minutes.
Last year, it partnered with the US Air Force and PE to develop its Mach 5 craft in order to support the presidential and executive fleet, and this March Hermeus announced that it was teaming up with NASA too.
Hypersonic travel is generally regarded as reaching speeds of Mach 5 or above, or five times the speed of sound. Hermeus successfully tested a Mach 5 engine prototype in February last year. "

Boom partnered with Japan Airlines (JAL), which pre-ordered 20 aircraft but now faces financial jeopardy. The Tokyo-based airline posted a $810 million operating loss in the third quarter, while its executives took a 10% salary reduction in April on the heels of the COVID-19 pandemic. That's their schedule and currently I don't see anything online indicating that it's not achievable. Always the risk of delays which is why I'm keeping some uncertainty but until I see a reason they wouldn't stick to their schedule I'll assume it's likely.

They have unveiled the fully assembled model and stated recently that the first test flight will be done in 2021. Moreover, they have stated in June 2020 that despite the coronavirus they remain in ”great cash position”. This is essential as their financiers and biggest potential future customers might not be.

Whilst the company are suggesting a test flight in 2021 that is it, which suggests very late in the year. Given the current climate, it probably will not take much to delay this by a couple of months into early 2022. That said, this is not quite bleeding edge technology - much of the tech is established, albeit not integrated to produce a supersonic aircraft.
Interesting, the question specifically states success is only take-off and landing - no supersonic flight. That makes success slightly easier to achieve, if only to allow Boom to claim they met their target, even if it is a short loop around the airfield using components that would not support supersonic flight.

The technology is available, Boom is being driven by industry and the bureaucracy of government won't slow it down. The Boeing 737 Max went from systems checks to first flight in one year. Boeing showed pictures of it's concept jet training in August of 2016 and the first aircraft was flown 4 months later. If the XB-1 takes 3x longer than the T-X, it will have its first flight in early '21.

https://www.nasa.gov/aeroresearch/nasa-marks-continued-progress-on-x-59 NASA is expected to begin flight tests in  Summer of 22. With a part of the building work being contracted to Lockheed they aren't done with assembly yet(expected to be completed by 2020) which means the XB1 is further ahead .Plus this being a startup will have less bureaucracy so should be able to get things done quicker. Since  all they are asking for is a simple takeoff and landing seems like pretty high probability event

Lockheed, Boeing and Northrup have all significantly reduced their historic testing timelines to meet new acquisition strategies.  This innovative private company, Boom, does not have the bureaucratic red tape involved in Defense Industrial Base processes and are honing and improving on existing tech.  Boom plans to conduct both ground testing and its first test flight in 2021 in the Mojave and that is highly likely given the advanced simulations that can be conducted beforehand.  The rollout of the prototype is complete so its on to testing...
Recent articles show the prototype. It was just the hull. Lots of work to get it flight ready. Won't happen in 2021

I think the chance a single successful test flight before Jan 1, 2022 is pretty good.  That being said, a whole lot can happen between now and then to delay a test flight.  Specifically I wonder if there could potentially be funding issues considering the devastation that the Covid-19 pandemic and the resulting lockdowns have had on the travel industry.

I'm surprised at how optimistic the crowd is. They've given a press release saying they will fly in 2021, but no details of what part of the year they are targeting, and a hundred things could cause delays. Approvals may take longer than expected, manufacturing, simulations, physically getting people where they need to be. The potential for the schedule being pushed back into 2022 seems very plausible imho.

Boom is relying on the publicity that Overture presents given that other supersonic programs are also running. Overture's test flight is going to be a great way to raise future funding as it gives Boom credibility. They're going to do everything they can to fly as soon as possible. The 5% chance is that they find an engineering flaw with the design that is completely unfixable with the current design (seems quite unlikely).

Seems very likely there will be test flight, will it be successful? Based on the interest from airlines, it seems as though Boom has a sound design. I believe it is highly probable they will conduct a successful test flight.
